image.altText: A group of Middle Eastern people stand in a car park next to a gated tin shed on sunny day

items.synopsis: What do you want to know about the Israel-Gaza war? Our global affairs correspondent John Lyons has been reporting from Israel along with the ABC team and is ready to answer your questions from 7:30pm AEDT. Follow live.

title.children: Ask our correspondent John Lyons your questions on the Israel-Gaza war

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The first flight to evacuate Australians from Israel has just left Tel Aviv. Foreign Minister Penny Wong says another flight is planned for the afternoon. It is currently midday in Israel. She added these two flights may be "our last flights for the foreseeable future". "Australians wanting to leave should strongly consider this option and not wait for a different option," she said on social media.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First flight leaves Tel Aviv as Australians urged to not wait for 'a different option'

children.content: The first flight to evacuate Australians from Israel has just left Tel Aviv.
Foreign Minister Penny Wong says another flight is planned for the afternoon. It is currently midday in Israel.
She added these two flights may be "our last flights for the foreseeable future".
"Australians wanting to leave should strongly consider this option and not wait for a different option," she said on social media.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's global affairs correspondent John Lyons is reporting from Israel along with the ABC team there and will be available to answer your questions from 7:30pm AEDT. You can share your questions by hitting the blue leave a comment button at the top of this stream.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Our correspondent John Lyons will be joining us for a Q&A shortly

children.content: The ABC's global affairs correspondent John Lyons is reporting from Israel along with the ABC team there and will be available to answer your questions from 7:30pm AEDT.
You can share your questions by hitting the blue leave a comment button at the top of this stream.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Nour Haydar Australians in Gaza are being “strongly encouraged” to move quickly to the Rafah border crossing. Nineteen Australian citizens are known to be in Gaza. The Department Foreign Affairs and Trade has sent a message to Australians in the area to move to the crossing in southern Gaza if they “assess it to be safe”, citing media reports that the crossing will be open to Australian citizens. “The situation is fluid and unpredictable but if you assess it to be safe, we strongly encourage you to move quickly to the Rafah crossing area now,” the DFAT message states. “We do not know when there will be another opportunity for you to depart Gaza or how long the crossing may be open.” Australians have been told they will be given more information once they have reached Egypt. “Do not delay your departure because you are uncertain of arrangement after you cross into Egypt,” the message said. “The Australian Government will provide details to you about the support that will be available to you in Egypt.” DFAT has told Australians that the Australian Government is seeking permission for other passport holders who are family members of Australian citizens to depart Gaza but “cannot guarantee authorities will permit other passport holders to exit”.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians in Gaza being urged to move to Rafah border

children.content: Australians in Gaza are being “strongly encouraged” to move quickly to the Rafah border crossing.
Nineteen Australian citizens are known to be in Gaza.

The Department Foreign Affairs and Trade has sent a message to Australians in the area to move to the crossing in southern Gaza if they “assess it to be safe”, citing media reports that the crossing will be open to Australian citizens.
“The situation is fluid and unpredictable but if you assess it to be safe, we strongly encourage you to move quickly to the Rafah crossing area now,” the DFAT message states.
“We do not know when there will be another opportunity for you to depart Gaza or how long the crossing may be open.”
Australians have been told they will be given more information once they have reached Egypt.
“Do not delay your departure because you are uncertain of arrangement after you cross into Egypt,” the message said.
“The Australian Government will provide details to you about the support that will be available to you in Egypt.”

DFAT has told Australians that the Australian Government is seeking permission for other passport holders who are family members of Australian citizens to depart Gaza but “cannot guarantee authorities will permit other passport holders to exit”.
